I just stumbled across this proof which type checks, even though I don't have Classical opened:

example : ¬(p → q) → p ∧ ¬q := by simp

It turns out that simp is rewriting with Init.Classical.not_forall here, which I find surprising. It looks like that theorem was added and tagged as @[simp] in this commit from February: https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/commit/8b0dd2e83517ebb3a2ac500fffbfe9125a32c439

Is this expected behavior for simp?
Derrik Petrin has marked this topic as resolved.
It seems like this should be marked scoped simp like the not_not thereom above it?
I will say, a tactic silently introducing a new axiom seems undesirable, generally (beyond any constructive/classical debate).
Last time it was discussed, Leo said that he isn't going to do anything to support non-classical reasoning. See, e.g., https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/pull/2412
This thread helped clarify the situation for me: #lean4 > Compartmentalization of axioms in Lean 4

Derrik Petrin said:

I will say, a tactic silently introducing a new axiom seems undesirable, generally (beyond any constructive/classical debate).

If its not about the classical vs constructive debate why is it undesirable? We know all of the axioms to be sound so using them at liberty unless you care about specific axiom sets (-> classical debate) doesnt seem to be an issue to me.

Henrik Böving said:

Derrik Petrin said:

I will say, a tactic silently introducing a new axiom seems undesirable, generally (beyond any constructive/classical debate).

If its not about the classical vs constructive debate why is it undesirable? We know all of the axioms to be sound so using them at liberty unless you care about specific axiom sets (-> classical debate) doesnt seem to be an issue to me.

All the axioms are sound as long as you restrict yourself to axioms which are already postulated in Lean. But, in some domains of mathematics, it makes sense to add or remove axioms, and formalize stuff in this new setting, and this is not necessarily about whether the theory on top of which you build the formalization is constructive or not. For instance, there is a "theorem" of game theory about winning strategies in infinite games which is inconsistent with the axiom of choice, but which you might want to study anyways, despite this having nothing to do with constructivism.
"All axioms are sound" is not a sound axiom. :upside_down:

You'd need to find a deeper embedding if you want to integrate nonclassical results into mathlib ... not sure if there is a preferred way to do it.
